results.title: Dragonheart [computer game]
results.brief_description: Based on the 1996 fantasy film of the same name, the player is Bowen, a dragon slayer for hire, who journeys through eight levels exploring the land, defeating thieves, fighting dragons and encountering characters from the film. Exploration is presented in a 1st-person-view while battles are more akin to a fighting game. In addition, the player can get information about the current quest from peasants in the villages littered throughout the game.

results.title: Dirt Track Racing [computer game]
results.material_description: CD-ROM videogame. CD-ROM, CD envelope, install instructions in cardboard box
results.brief_description: In Dirt Track Racing, the player controls a vehicle in a race around oval or figure-eight dirt tracks. The game features three classes of cars - stock, pro stock, and late model - which can be enhanced with high performance parts. The game allows you to either play one race or go through a career mode where the player starts with next to nothing and slowly accumulates more money and better cars through winning races and gaining sponsors. The player can also race up to 10 people online.

results.title: Decisive Battles of World War II: Ardennes Offensive [computer game]
results.material_description: CD-ROM videogame. CD-ROM, CD jewel case with insert, manual, read me guide, registration card and epilepsy warning in cardboard box
results.brief_description: Decisive Battles of WWII: Ardennes Offensive is the first game in the Decisive Battles of WWII series. It is a turn-based strategy wargame set in the Battle of the Bulge. The player can play as either the Germans or Americans, with the British as an AI-controlled third faction. Gameplay is primarily set on a hexagonal grid map with regiments being represented by icons. In each turn, which represents a half day, the player can move units or attack enemy units. A unit’s effectiveness can be augmented by several factors like artillery or airstrikes. The game comes with eight scenarios with a varying number of turns in which to complete them. These scenarios can be played against the computer or against friends in hot seat, LAN, online or play-by-email modes.

results.title: Dark Reign: The Future of War [computer game]
results.material_description: CD-ROM videogame. CD-ROM, CD jewel case with insert, manual, product registration card, adverts, internet guide sheet and keyboard reference in cardboard box
results.brief_description:
In the grim future of Dark Reign: The Future of War, the player is caught between two factions at war, the Imperium and the Freedom Guard. The player has a chance to go back in time using a time-travelling device and change history but must first complete a set of trails to activate it. Each of these scenarios has the player recreating past battles between the Imperium and Freedom Guard to prove to hone their martial skills.

Each faction has its own unique units, skills and weaknesses. The Freedom Guard are weaker but more mobile, allowing them to better to be faster and handle difficult terrain. The Imperium, in contrast, have the strength and numbers to overwhelm their enemies but are generally slower. These traits lend themselves to radically different playstyles. A player can also steal the other faction’s technology using a specialized unit, negating their opponent’s advantages. The game features a campaign and map editor and supports online play. In fact, there is still an active community despite the game being over 20 years old.

results.title: College Slam [computer game]
results.brief_description:
Part of the NBA Jam series of basketball games, College Slam allows the player to choose from 44 real college teams and take part in head-to-head games, tournaments, and season-long series in arcade-style two-on-two frenetic gameplay. Each side starts out by picking any two out of five players from a team to play with. During timeouts and half-time, the player has a choice to make substitutions. Making three baskets in a row without the other team scoring, powers the player up which makes it easier to score.

This points to the unrealistic nature of the game, where players can make full-court shots with relative ease, characters frequently jump higher than the net and may get struck by lightning during dunks. The game features customizable teams and players and fight songs from all the available teams.

results.title: Cricket 97: Ashes Tour Edition [computer game]
results.material_description: CD-ROM videogame. CD-ROM, CD jewel case with insert and manual in a cardboard box
results.brief_description: A sequel to Cricket 96 and an expansion to Cricket 97, Cricket 97: Ashes Tour Edition further improves on the series’ graphics, featuring stadiums rendered in three-dimensions, a series first. Cricketing legends Ritchie Benaud and Ian Botham have been added to provide commentary and are featured in full motion video interludes. The Ashes Tour Edition introduces enhancements such as real players’ names and stats, a larger stadium, an instant replay function, and minor gameplay improvements.

Cricketing legends Ritchie Benaud and Ian Botham have been added to provide commentary and are featured in full motion video interludes. The Ashes Tour Edition introduces enhancements such as real players’ names and stats, a larger stadium, an instant replay function, and minor gameplay improvements.

The Ashes Tour Edition introduces enhancements such as real players’ names and stats, a larger stadium, an instant replay function, and minor gameplay improvements.

results.title: Cricket 96 [computer game]
results.material_description: CD-ROM videogame. CD-ROM in CD jewel case with insert and manual
results.brief_description: A sequel to Super International Cricket, Cricket 96 allows the player to set up the field, bowlers and batsmen and play either test or one-day matches. It improved on the graphics of its predecessor and features eight teams, although it forgoes official team or player licensing. However, many of the in-game players have recognizable real-life counterparts, albeit without their actual names.

results.title: Choplifter II [computer game]
results.material_description: Cartridge videogame. Cartridge, cartridge case and manual in cardboard box
results.brief_description: In this sequel to Choplifter!, the player has to fly a rescue helicopter through levels to pick up stranded hostages. Complicating matters are the planes, bullets and even aggressive birds that get in the helicopter’s way, not to mention buildings and hills. Rescuing a given number of hostages will complete a level and saving more hostages than required leads to extra points and lives. Inversely, taking too much damage or losing too many hostages will lead to lost extra lives.

results.title: Carriers at War 1941-1945: Fleet Carrier Operations in the Pacific [DOS]
results.material_description: Floppy disk videogame. Two 3 1/2 inch floppy disks, colour map, product registration card, subscription card and manual in a cardboard box
results.brief_description:
Carriers at War 1941-1945: Fleet Carrier Operations in the Pacific is a war simulation game. In the game, the player takes on the role of the task force commander in the Pacific Theater during World War II. The player can play as both the U.S. and the Japanese Empire in scenarios such as Pearl Harbor, Coral Sea, Midway, Eastern Solomons, Santa Cruz and Philippine Sea. The game is played on a 72x84 hexagonal grid on which different units and squadrons, such as naval vessels and land based aircraft, are positioned. The player chooses actions for these units, the consequences for which are simulated by the computer. The game is quasi real-time, meaning that the game can be paused at any given moment at which time the player can give orders to the units. All interaction with the game is through a menu interface. Orders that can be given to units include strike, escort, transport, support, refuel and more complex maneuvers such as strike routines.

Source: Play It Again website:
http://www.ourdigitalheritage.org/archive/playitagain/games/goldfields/

Last accessed: 6/05/2021

Original game developed by Strategic Studies Group for Commodore 64, published in 1984 by Strategic Studies Group
